div1.p: Carter reports success with the early Italian references and discusses the progress of her work.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, November 28, 1928
div1.opener:
Book, Misel
Report (weekly)
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
November 28, 1928.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
Miss Brown and I have gotten a lot done this week, inculluding
having the authority on early Italian at the Library of Congress
go over the text of a good part of the account of “The Portuguese
Pilot” (who first visited São Thomé in 1520) and that of Alvise Cà da
Mosto, one of the African explorers for Prince Henry of Portugal.
We had already gotten things pretty well verified ourselves, but the
verbatim quotations are too important, in both cases, not to get them
“ex cathedra,” when, as has been the case in all our work, people
specially qualified to help us along our different lines of inquiry,
have been not only readywilling, but eager to do so. In this connection,
I got an extremely kind letter from Dr. L. O. Howard the other day,
telling me not to hesitate to call on him at any time for any help that
he could give me. The only person to whom I have applied from whom
I have not heard is Dr. J. W. W. Stevens. I do hope he isn't sick.
Mr. Neumann, of the Library of the Surgeon General, was at the Library
of Congress yesterday and I gave him a duplicate of the references
about which I had written to Stephens, which he says he will investi-
gate in every way available to him. Miss Brown and I have already almost
“worked our heads off” over them, (so has Frost), but perhaps Mr. Neumann
may have better luck. Stephens was the method of election, as the
references were to Bacot's and to Stephens' own work (unpublished when
Father wrote this part of the MS). Frost says, however, that it must
have been published subsequently, either under Stephens' name or in some
report. Its needless to say that both methods of approach have already
been tried--hard. Of course, we can put these refs. in the bibliogra-
bibliogra-

phy as Father had it, i. e. as from personal communications and un-
published MS, but, as Frost says, it will be much more satisfactory
to the reader if we can cite matter in published form., hence easy of ac

This is a bit early in the week to write, but Miss Brown, who
has a half holiday, is coming up to work with me this afternoon, at
my apartment. She will spend the night and we will begin again right
after breakfast tohmorrow (Thanksgiving Day). Well, I certainly have
much to be thankful for in that the work is going so well. This despite the
fact that my digestion has been doing a tailspin for 21 days, that Ive [unclear]
in my rt. arm & that my left eye is pretty well out of commis
commission
for the
past six
weeks.

Dr. Frost has a bad cold. or “flu,” I don't know which. At any
rate, although he has been working on Father's MS since his return from
Cincinnati, he does not yet feel that he wishes me to go over to
Baltimore. Had a long talk on the subject night before last(long
distance) with Mrs. Frost.

p.del:
What of the “Hun” gentleman” and his yellow fever “cure?” Not
much, I fancy.

div1.closer:
With best wishes, I remain
Most truly yours, Laura A. Carter Dr. Frederick F. Russell,
Director,
International Health Division,
The Rockefeller Foundation,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
